column11: Review Text

column8: My favorite national park in Sri Lanka (and I was in all)
column11: Kumana NP is one of the most beautiful parks in the world, especially when the many lakes within are filled with water. You will then see countless birds, from the ibis to 5 diverse stork species, but also many Crocs, occasionally an elephant, wild boar and Axish - and, yes, leopards. Their density is said to be highest here in the world, not in Yala, for example. Kumana is never as crowded as neighbouring Yala, probably because most of Arugam are just for surfing or bathing...the drive here alone takes around an hour, but is scenically really super nice. Of course, good luck is always part of an animal observation, of course, sighting a leopard is never guaranteed. Beautiful places to get out and legs represented on the Kumbuk-lined shore of an inlet in the park

column8: Kumana: Where Nature Whispers and History Waits
column11: his is a park bird lovers should not miss. Located in the southeastern corner of Sri Lanka, Kumana has preserved its pristine natural beauty. The drive from Arugam Bay is among the finest—evoking memories of colonial-era roadworks. With untouched jungle on one side and the shimmering sea on the other, the journey infuses an energetic sense of wonder. For those interested in Buddhist culture, Kudumbigala Monastery is another must-visit on this trip. With a history spanning over 2,000 years, its serene isolation has helped preserve the site's authenticity and spiritual charm.

Great safari if you like birds. Lots of different birds. Very very bad roads so your back in peril constantly. You don't expect a smooth ride on most safaris but this was exceptionally rough.We saw no elephants, no leopards and no bears. A few distant crocodiles and lots of peacocks. The scenery was pretty  but would  not go again or recommend.

column8: Half day jeep safari of Kumana national park
column11: Four of us did a half day jeep safari at Kumana national park from 5 A.M. to 11 AM. with Mr. Shantha in his jeep. He is an expert on the Kumana and nearby areas such as Kudumbigala. He took us on the trail very safely till the boundary of Yala along the coast and sometimes in the interior. We met a few other similar jerps with local and foreign tourists. We saw all the animals and birds at the park except for bear and leopard. Leopards and bear had been seen the previous day but we were not lucky on this day. We saw herds of elephants with young ones, a lot of deer, not so usual types of colourful birds, huge crocodiles and a lot of peacocks too. We witnessed at least 3 great peacock dances with full blown feather presentation. We can highly recommend Mr. Shantha (+94 77 662 5337) for leafing a half or full day safari jeep tour of Kumana and adjacent areas. By Lucky Jayaratne

They came to pick us up at the hotel at the right time. During the journey to the park, the driver has already indicated animals. During the safari, the driver showed us fauna and different areas with different vegetation. We saw quite a lot of local fauna... and even one of us spotted a leopard. All very well. Recommended experience for fauna and landscape. We'd be back.

I am absolutely thrilled to talk about Kumana National Park, located on the southeastern coast of Sri Lanka, bordering the Indian Ocean. This biodiverse paradise is a haven for wildlife enthusiasts, boasting an incredible array of fauna and flora that are unique to this region. What makes Kumana stand out is its status as an important bird sanctuary, with over 200 species of birds including rare and endangered species like the black-necked stork and greater flamingo. In addition to birdwatching opportunities, visitors can also spot elephants, leopards, sloth bears, and many other animals in their natural habitat. The park's mix of wetlands, forests, and grasslands create a stunning landscape that offers a different kind of safari experience compared to other national parks in Sri Lanka. Truly a must-visit destination for any nature lover!

There were less than 10 vehicles when we arrived in the morning.  The trip was pleasant after the crowd at Yala even though there seemed to be less animals and birds.    Kumana is swampier than Yala but beautiful in its own way.  And we saw a leopard too!  We also saw more elephants around Kumana compared to Yala.

An excellent reserve for the Watching edge but also for leopards and bears. The diversity and beauty of the landscapes as well as its Buddhist ruins make it the favorite playground of photographers. To visit!

This National park which I think was called Yala East is a beautiful park with a good mixture of open park, large lakes/tanks and dense jungle. Very few jeeps enter the park so it is very relaxed and the animal/ bird life seems to completely oblivious to those. Similarly the jeep drivers are very relaxed and take plenty of time. Few vehicle tracks. Main problem is that the park entrance is 15-20 kilometres from Panama along a very rough dirt track. But well worth the effort. The local guides say the afternoon safaris are best for animals and the morning safaris for birds. We did one of each and didn’t notice a difference.

Being to Kumana National Park many times and this time we did an afternoon private safari. Located in the south coast of Sri Lanka and is the eastern sector of Yala. Less crowded. More famous for bird watching. Even though it was from far, we saw a leopard. So lucky to witness a sloth bear walking down the bridge. Unable to attach the video. Definitely the highlight of our safari.

Good sightings of wild life without disturbance from other park visitors. Plenty of unusual sightings besides the elephant, leopard, bear, wild boar, buffalo. We saw an eagle hunting down a lizard and two red mongoose digging out their breakfast snake. The best way to enjoy the park is to book a camp site with generally luxury with extreamnaturetours.com

I would say this is my favourite park. We were lucky to see 4 leopard, 3 tuskers and lot of wild animals and lot of endemic birds and migrative birds in one day. Our trackers and Park owners were very supportive. Special thanks goes to Mr. Samaranayake for the support.

DO NOT GO THERE!! We were there at the 14 of juni in 2023. It was so that bad, i dont know where to start. - Costs around 12'000 per person - Driver drove more like he was at a racing car - GARBAGE ALL OVER THE "REST" AREAS AND FIRES,Because there was a religion walk from jaffna to there. - Saw 1 Elephant,and 2 buffalos thats it. - arround 2000 people who walk trough the park for this religion walk.....SAD I know its nature and u can not expect everything,but i really dont want to pay for an NATIONAL PARK WHO IS FULL OF PLASTIC BOTTLES. Common its a Nationl park an not anything else, really sad.... I DO NOT RECOMMEND IT. If you have time and money, go on Safari in Afrika as we are last year. Of course expensier BUT mooooost better then this.

the park is really good and less crowded but the road to it needs repairs very badly. it is a nightmare to travel to such a beautiful park.  With Arugambey surf season coming up if our tourism paternity gets together and synergy it with Kumana safari, it will help a grade deal as Arigambay is more or less like Hikkaduwa now.  the tallest but rare bird of Sri Lanka - black necked Stroke - and a leopard roaming around were seen in addition to numerous elephants and a majestic tusker .

Kumana, is trule a gem for wildlife enthusiasts. One of the best Sri Lankan National Parks to spot Sri Lankan Leopards (Panthera Pardus Kotiya).  Park is also not as crowded as other nearby national parks such as Yala.
My absolute favorite NP in SL! Always see so many animals and very few visitors. A must go. You can stay in Arugam bay as its a close drive from there!
It is one of the best birding destinations in Sri Lanka. We recommend the Kumana national park for bird lovers and wildlife holiday seekers. while in Arugambay for surfing activity.

Kumana NP is one of the most peaceful parks where you can just enjoy nature and the animals in their natural habitat. Limited number of vehicles are in the park. The park has two Wildlife bungalows inside the park. Staying in one of those is a blessings since you have to drive for an hour from Arugambay/Pottuvil Area. The park has so many leopards as well as a paradise for Birds. Migratory season is the best for Kumana. The road to the park (Kudumbigala area) is a bit of a tough one. If you have a jeep or SUV it would be ideal. Inside the park you can hire a jeep and go on Safari's A park that is so much more peaceful than the Yala or the wildpattu.
Nice park with lots of animals, but not many tourists. Plenty of buffalos, wild pigs, deer, we also saw foxes, mongoose and an elephant. Myriad of birds, any bird lover will be thrilled.
This is one of the hidden delights of Sri Lanka - a very special place with lots of wildlife and gorgeous scenery!

Very nice half day trip! The park is smaller, almost without tourists and with luck you can see a leopard! I recommend more than Yala Park itself, it's much quieter here and elephants are almost everywhere.

Kumana national park is also called Yala East. It is a lot smaller than Yala and much less crowdy. We booked in Arugam Bay and paied 5000 LKR each, which included everything: entrance fee, 4x4 and driver/guide. You stay in the park for about 4 hours. We were lucky and saw all kinds of animals among which elephants and even a leopard.

Did an afternoon safari (seems more common than morning).  Left at 1:30pm and came back at 7:30pm.  We saw too many animals to list here!  The only one we didn't see is the leopard.  The road to the park was very dusty.  Bring binoculars. July 15th 2019, the standard price was 4300-4500SRL per person for shared safari or 16000SRL if you want to hire a private vehicule(both peice include everything: guide, entrance fee, etc).
Excellent Place to Visit, Please enter the park as Early as possible, In the Morning the scenery is very beautiful
It was a great day to us at kumana. Nice place to visit with families and friends. Different kind of birds, lizards, snakes and nice environment. Hope to visit again with my family.

Tip 1 - Wanna spot the most elusive animal in the world, Leopard? Contact Manaf (0779690896) The way our driver tracked down the leopard was simply incredible! On that day almost every jeep we encountered said the leopards are no where to be found and they all left by 5.30 pm. But our driver was so determined and kept on repeating a small route (which he guessed there could be a leopard hiding) over and over again. When he repeated the same route for the 3rd time we got frustrated (thinking he's deceiving us) and almost asked him to leave the park. But when we came back for the 4th lap we were shocked to see some fresh leopard footprints over the tyre marks on the road (it had waited for us to move and then crossed the road!). Then he quickly took us to another route deep into the forest, all of a sudden booom the bad guy appeared on the road out of nowhere. The sighting lasted for about 5 min and we were the only jeep around :) By the end of the trip we almost ended up spotting all the animals the park had to offer! Tip 2 - Although we did the full day safari I guess an evening trip could be enough for you to spot all the main animals.

The best of three stays in national parks this trip . Small group and solo specialist Extreme Nature Camp for three nights was a revelation in peaceful and beautiful river side simple camping with comforts. Highly qualified and experienced guiding and spotting in uncrowded locations let us experience animal behaviors not just ticking of a top five list. Personal favourite an encounter with King mongoose pair and a lovely Russells Viper. Exceptional waterbirding in this Ramsar listed lagoon landscape . Highly recommended.

We visited the park one week ago, and I can tell you that it was great. We are luckly enough to take our road, and we travel through the park along with our friendly ranger. The animals were so cute and amazing.

It is one of the best safari locations in Sri Lanka. We started the tour at about 02.30 pm. We were lucky enough to watch lot of birds. Dancing peacocks can be seen everywhere. There were few elephants close to the road. It was a really fantastic experience for me and my girlfriend.
One of the best place to watch endemic birds in Sri Lanka. Must visit early in the morning to have a better experience

Relatively smaller national park located in the eastern province, in continuation with yala national park. But cannot visit yala from Kumana without special permission. You have to hire a safari jeep from Arugambay or panama. Usually half a day is enough. Much less crowded than yala. But lesser animals and birds compared to yala.

This is a bounty of nature indeed! Wonderful place where you can collect lots of experience with respect to extremely rare  types of colorful birds, animals reptiles etc.  Compare to other national parks in Sri Lanka, Kumana is a calm and quiet place where you can enjoy the unique fascinating beauty of the nature intact till now. The safari guide provide by the wild life office had also done his best to make us understand the nature of the place, birds, animals, and its persistence under the thorough control of the wild life department.

Such a beautiful scenic jungle with a variety of animals, birds and reptiles. One can enjoy the park as it is not spoilt with too many visitors and vehicles. Roaming animals have their freedom and we can enjoy the viewimg them in their Marital habitat. People of the country has to value these without dumping their rubbish out of their vehicles as plastics can be seen around and feel sorry. Authorities must take more care about the people who stay overnight in those rented bungalows with stringent rules requesting them to take their own rubbish out as they dump their alcohol empty bottles out in the beach and under the trees. Animals have left their foot prints only on the sand, beach and its so admirable while people leave their rubbish in a vergin jungle having a brain to think that it does not decay for centuries. Enjoy the view of the nature and leave nothing other than the type marks.

We saw so many different animals, elephants, crocodiles, colorful and big birds, buffalos, deers etc!! Also the area was really beautiful. We spent there about 5hours and after almost lost our hope to see leopard, we saw three(!!!) on the same road and also hear their voice from the jungle. It was almost 6pm and I think we were last ones there, we were so lucky! We book our tickets from Arugam travels. The driver was as excited about the leopards as we were, he stop the car on the road and we just sit there and wait to see them. This is also called Yala east national park, you can see same animals here than there but there are less people and less cars.

This park is amazing. We did 3 safaris while in Sri Lanka, they were all great but and this was our favourite. The park was so quiet, we only saw one other jeep the whole afternoon, which was so refreshing after our busy safari at Kaudulla NP. The animals were abundant and so much variety. We saw elephants, buffalo, spotted deer, mongoose, countless birds, crocodiles. The only thing we weren't lucky to see was a leopard, maybe next time. The park itself is well kept and had a variety of environments. We just loved it. Our guide had a good eye and pointed out lots of animals, unfortunately we didnt get his name, but his picture is below, he was lovely and tried really hard to spot a leopard for us. If your in the area and love animals do this safari.

I liked the park more than expected. We visited mid/end of September and saw lots of water buffaloes, deer, some elephants (one was really close and we could watch it for a while), crocodiles, monkeys, mungos and many colourful birds. Other groups even seemed to have spotted a leopard. Also there were not too many Jeeps, at times it felt as if we were the only ones there. Furthermore the landscape alone is just stunning and varies a lot throughout the park. In my opinion Kumana is a great option for people who want to avoid the crowds and want to see some local fauna in their natural habitat, but do not necessarily need to see huge herds of elephants and see spotting leopards as a nice bonus and not as the main reason to visit the park.

I was expecting this to be mainly birds but we were about 5 metres from a leopard, saw crocodiles and such an excellent range of birds. Really quiet when we went, around 6am, with hardly another car in sight.Highly, highly recommended.

Amazing experience with Arugambay tour and his collaborators!! Manà, the driver, was really kind and explained carefully everything to us. We went for a nice swim in river in the park and saw really close elephants, crocodiles, buffalos, deers etc. The food also was great. We recommend this tour.
not as populated as other national parks! real safari experience with tracking of animals is needed. good for bird watching in November to January.
A very  nice place, you can see a lot of animals. Birds they looks so nice, elephants, leopard, crocodile and so on. The tour was with arugam bay tours. They are very good organizer

The safari we booked was very poorly organized. A jeep broke down during the safari, so that it could only drive very slowly, our jeep had to stay behind all the time and could / did not want to overtake. In addition, our Jeep was in a very bad condition, dirty and with limited visibility. The return trip was therefore unbearably long. From the provider there was not even an apology at the end of the tour, which would have been the least, after all the circumstances!
This park is next to Yala so it has a similar variety of wildlife but we were some of the only jeeps in the park. We saw 3 leopards walking down the dirt road, plenty of elephants etc

Booked a shared trip with Lemon Tree travel company in Arugam Bay. It cost us LKR 4500 per person. We had 2 other couples as well as one subdue traveller with us on our jeep. I would say the shared option was really good as it was lighter on the pocket for us, while we also got to meet some fellow travellers. If you hire the jeep solo from Lemon Tree the quote was around LKR 14000. We were super pleased with Lemon Tree’s service all around. We asked around all the tour companies in Arugam Bay before finalising, and we found most of them either not transparent or not properly communicative. In particular the guy in Ceylon Walking tours lied to us overstating the government entree fees to the park as LKR 4500 (when its common knowledge that it’s arounf LKR 2200) and also lied to us that the pilgrimage season was in November even though it was happening then. Manas from Lemon Tree on the other hand came across as a very ethical salesperson staying everything transparently and not trying to increase prices for us even when we were in a rush towards the end. Lemon tree was also the only one who arranged shared trips; all other operators would only arrange singular trips and if you want to share you would’ve to find other travellers! The drive through Kumana National park was fun. We had quite a few close elephant sightings. Buffaloes, birds, deers and monkeys we sighted in the plentiful. I also had a fleeting glimpse at a leopard before the shy animal strode off into the brush. I can imagine why they say it’s a birder’s paradise. Even though I am not a bird watcher I found the sheer variety of birds amazing. One tip would be to avoid going on weekends though as the number of jeeps in the park would be relatively higher as the locals too would be in to watch the animals on their day off. But again it’s still way less crowded than any other park I have been to, so go for it if you can’t pick any other day.

We booked our tour with the Ceylon Walking Tours office on the main Street in Arugam Bay. Nice company and okay pricing. The Safari truck could hold 6 passengers, we are a group of three, so they found a couple to join us. This was nice. Half day safari is fine - full day might be too much driving around. The roads are bunoy which adds to the experience. Our driver was great, friendly and abit knowledgeable.  He had a good eye for spotting animals. We saw three solo elephants and lots of deer and water buffalo, and crocodiles. We thought that maybe our Safari included. Guide but this wasn't the case - but that was okay. If you are a bird watcher this place would be paradise! Also nice for anybody to see the natural surroundings.

If you a birding guy this is the place you should visit. We saw more than 27 different species of birds within 1 square kilometer. No traffic inside the park as there were few jeeps running for the whole park.

Started our safari around 1.30 pm and main target was to see leopard & bear. From Panama to park entrance is about 45 min as the roads are bumpy and unsealed. After paying entrance fee we were joined by a tracker - Chanaka who had a good knowledge and an eagle eye to look for animals. Within half an hour we were thrilled to see a leopard under a tree. In two seconds he slowly disappeared into bushes. Guaranteed sight in KNP is water buffaloes, Spotted deer, wild fox and wild pigs. Saw a crocodile resting on the bank. Bird information centre  where there is a tower overlooks the lagoon is the best place to watch birds. Fantastic info about different kind of birds on the walls at lookout point. Even though KNP is rich in bird life and most popular bird sanctuary in SL, we saw only few of them. Green bee eaters are commonly seen. Road conditions inside the park is much better than Yala NP. Better to start early morning or mid afternoon. On our way back saw a leopard in the treetop. As it was getting dark, didn't see him clearly. Well worth 4.5 hrs drive. Will be back to see bears and more birds later !!

Less busy compared to Yala National Park, Kumana National Park boasts a wide range of wildlife including a large number of birds, mammals, lakes and trees. It's a bit hard to spot leopards or bears, but you're very likely to spot other animals like elephants, deer, buffalo etc.

Visited Kumana national park for two days as it was the first visit to this area for my wife and kids. Had a pleasant safari with lots of birds, elephants, two Bears (mother and cub) and finally a leopard on our final game drive before leaving. My main intention was to see a tusker as the last tusker I saw in kumana was the late great "Poottuwa" before 2003 Had an enjoyable time at the Edakumbuka 1 campsite. The park was full of water so it was difficult to see much animals, visited the ruins of the Kumana village and school which brought me back memories of the village which I visited a few times as a young boy.

The park: Had a great variety of animals. We saw jungle fowl, mongoose, wild boars, peacocks galore, samba and spotted deer, buffallo, monkeys, crocodiles and elephants. It wasn't very crowded, maybe 4 other jeeps were spotted. Gorgeous mangrove area with lookout point. Very interesting trees and birds. Best safari we had in Sri Lanka for variety of animals and sparsity of humans! The tour: Our tour was organized through our accommodation and it was definitely overpriced! 160 000 LAKs for 2 people. I would have really loved seat belts for the drive to and from the park, the driver was speeding through the local streets and it was bumpy, was quite nervous at times. Once in the park, he respected the speed limits. Their was no guide included, and he was not able to answer any questions in english about the animals or park. He went outside of the jeep at one point and picked up large mushrooms and peacock feathers until a local park ranger caught him and he had to put them back. He kept intimidating the elephants, even after we repeatedly asked to keep moving as we didn't want to scare them (we understand when it's for our safety if a lone male elephant shows signs of aggressivity, but this one was not). Finally at the end he asked for a tip which we said was included in the price of the tour.

The tour I went on was poorly managed by Arugam Bay Khan Surfaris, located across the road from no worries restaurant. We paid 5000rupees per person for 6 people and a four hour tour with an English speaking guide. The steering of the safari jeep broke 10 seconds into the tour before we made it onto the road. We waited for an hour before a guy rocked up in a tuk tuk and started welding on the bottom of the car. We then set off again only for the engine to stop working 100m down the road. We then waited while they organised another jeep. Finally we set off on the tour of the park 2 hours later than planned. Since we were so late and the park closes 630pm they refunded 1000rupees, which is the normal price they charge for the short tour. When we got to the park gates at 350pm we were told there would be no guide. We had requested both when we booked and on the day of the tour to have a guide, and they assured me this would be arranged. The park itself is lovely, with lots of elephants, birds, deer, hogs, and buffalo. I would happily recommend it. We left the park after a bit less that 2hr30min. I explained I was unsatisfied with the tour and expected a partial refund as no guide was supplied, but no refund was given. Given the tour was shorter than even their shortest advertised tour and with no guide this is not good enough. Do visit Kumana national Park but avoid Arugam Bay Khan Surfaris.

I got the opportunity to have a Jeep Safari to kumana National park during my annual staff trip to Arugam bay. kumana Safari is the best safari I have in Sri Lanka so far with many u forgettable memories. Overall there are few reasons to be made this journey most attractive. First is the timing chosen for the Safari. It is January so that after having some rains whole park is in lush greenery. We started the journey from Arugam bay at about 2.30 pm and after about one hour travel we reached to the Kumana National park entrance. Total safari inside the park was about 3 hours from 3.30 to 6.30 pm so that it is one of the best time to see animals in kumana. Second reason; Kumana is still remain untouched by many visitors and Safari is not yet spoiled by lot of jeeps at once like in some other National parks in Sri Lanka. In some other parks it seems nos. Of jeeps are more than the animals in the park hence can not feel and enjoy the real Safari. In kumana, most attractively there are lot of animals and birds with many verities. Deers , elephants , wild bore, buffaloes , peacocks & many migrant birds, crocadiles and many others. Unforgettable climax point of the Safari is we were very lucky to see a leopard at very close distance. This is very rare opportunity in Sri Lanka and some travelers have to spend over night in camping site to eye catch such a scenery . So Kumana safari is recommended as one of the best safari in Sri Lanka . We all 4 jeeps together in this journey and paid Rs. 6000/- per seven seated Jeep for its whole journey of 5 hours

it's a very beautiful place. it's located in pothuvil city. mostly if you go to arugamby don't forget go to kumana national park. its a 1.30 hore jurny to inside the forest. full and full natural and you can see the live animals. you can't go by walk to the inside. you have to hire a safari vehicle for that. more info +94779992177 what's up me

Lovely place to visit during the season. Can see thousands of different variety of non natiove birds flown from thousands of kilometers to have their summer holiday here in Kumana marshy lands. Do not forget to carry a binoculars if you want to watch the birds seriously. Beautiful drive in a 4 wheel drive through waterways. Lots of Elephants,Lepords, deer, Elk,Water Buffolows. It was a fantastic journey with a very good tracker and the park office you get loads of information about its habitat. Can visit the "Kuda Kabilittha", devalaya too on this visit.

We had a great time in this place. The landscape is really beautiful and we saw all the animals expected to see, even de elusive leopard. It is not a crowded place so you can enjoy the nature in relative calm, but we also had a sad feeling as we realized that every two meters there was plastic rubbish along the sides of every path. We found plastic bottles and bags scattered everywhere near the paths inside the National Park. Authorities and neglectful visitors should be ashamed of this situation. Surprisingly, other more crowded National Parks, such as Horton or Kaudulla, were much more clean.
The early morning safari is the best for birds watching as we saw so many birds during 4 hr safari. While on the way back, you can visit Kudumbigala temple which has a unique physical location.

We made a 6-hours safari in the national park in a jeep with a Sri Lankan driver. We saw all we wanted to see (elephants, leopard, deers...) even if there was a pilgrimage crossing the park. Really great moment!

I think we were the unlucky ones that didn't get to see groups of elephants which is all we wanted to see. We saw one elephant in the far distance and then one elephant in the bushes and one outside the park heading to the beach. Everyone else I spoke to that had done this tour said they saw loads of elephants. There were lots of water buffulo and deers plus we saw some crocodiles towards the end. Oh and lots of peacocks plus monkeys at one stop.  Need to take a good camera. Prices to vary a bit we paid 5,500 LKR per person  including jeep and entry.
I've enjoyed the yala safari better - for the size of this national park there aren't many living there.

We opted for an early morning tour of the park, departing at 5am from Arugam Bay. A jeep with Ceylon Walking Tours cost 8,000LKR including driver and guide, and we split it among 4 people. The journey to the park entrance takes about 40 minutes. We arrived as the park opened up at 6am. Entrance for 4 tourists was 8600LKR, so 2150LKR each. As with everything else in Sri Lanka, it is much cheaper for locals, and you do get the feeling you are once again just subsidising their own domestic tourism industry, rather than supporting a good cause. The climate is noticeably cooler at this time of day. The park is enormous. We spent about 4 hours there in total, driving all the way to the river which divides it and Yala Strict Natural Reserve. Along the way we spotted one large and very surprised elephant, mongooses, deer, crocs, water buffalo and numerous wild bird species (although our guide informed us that we had missed the main migratory season to see all the bird life). All the while we were desperately looking for any sign of a leopard, straining our eyes up to every tree branch and rock we passed. However despite bumping along miles of track, all we saw were pawprints. Disappointing but given a park of this size where animals are also free to roam into Yala, understandable. It was a shame because we did feel we were mis-sold the trip a little, in that we were assured the morning would be a great time to spot leopards, and many visitors had seen them recently. Go with limited expectations, and a packed lunch, and you won't be disappointed!

We had a lovely safari at Kumana. We entered the park around 2.30pm by jeep and we paid 2150 rupees each, including tax. We drove around there for four hours and got to see pretty much everything. From the most colourful birds to foxes, crocodiles, a turtle, elephants, deer, buffalo's, some small alligators (sorry don't know the name) and to top it all off, we even spotted a leopard which was amazing!! Even without spotting that though, I would definitely recommend. We saw about 3 other jeeps and that's it.

The best Safari Location in Sri Lanka where you can see many animals and birds. You have to stay in the park bungalow - Thummulla - for the best experience.  Very few safari jeeps which gives lot of freedom for animals and viewers. So don't go there just for fun - only if you really love watching them

We went on safari with Ecowave (based in Arugam Bay). It was so good!! We went in the morning and saw elephants, water buffalo, deer etc. There's lots of birds because of the lagoons. Such a gorgeous place and we were the only visitors - didn't see any other jeeps at all. Our guide was able to answer the endless questions I had about the animals and the park. We had breakfast by the birds information centre.

We went in the afternoon and saw tons of wildlife and no other jeeps! The scenery was stunning too. Would definitely recommend. Just make sure to bring food and water with you and wear comfortable clothes; it's a long time in a car!
They are the best camping outfit in SL and their understanding of the National Parks, the flora and fauna within is fantastic. Highly recommend them

Our safari jeep combed through the lush greeny trees and streams.. the extend from the entrance to the border end, it took us solidly nearly 2 hours to reach. Expect bumpy sand roads throughout. At few locations, our jeep drove through small water streams - which was really exciting. The day before we went, the park have received a good amount of rain, thus inundating a few access roads. Our driver used some alternative routes and reached till the end of the park, which ends with a narrow river, the other bank of the river is the Yala National Park. On your way make sure you keep silent. Loud noises (shouts, screams, talking loudly) can scare away the animals and birds. Please make sure you don't disturb the wildlife as it's their home and we are just visitors. There are leopards, crocodiles, sloth bears, elephants on the way and plenty of herds of deer and peacocks. Bring plenty of water and wear a comfortable clothing, the climate is fairly hot. It's always recommended not to take plastic bags into the forest. Bring back what ever you take inside. Same like many other national parks, you are not allowed to get down from your vehicle, unless it's been adviced by your designated forest officer. There's a large mangrove reserve which looks stunning. It's a bird watcher's paradise, I'd say. Overall, our visit was really worthwhile and the entire safari took nearly 4 hours.
This is one of the best wildlife park located in Sri Lanka. This park is good place to see birds. This is belongs to one of the Ramsa protected wetlands in Sri Lanka

Had a fantastic time inside the park with Jumbos, all sorts of birds & most importantly with three unforgettable sightings of well built young healthy Leopards. Although I have been in most other national parks in the island, Kumana was the park that had the best of the variety in wildlife.

We spent a day inside Kumana national park with a safari driver. It was not that dry due to wet days in the previous days. We were lucky enough to watch lot of birds. There were few elephants close to the road. We enjoyed watching dancing peacocks everywhere. Thanks to safari driver and park guide, we had a wonderful day.
We spent the day with by brothers and a friend of ours. It was a pretty dry time of the year and we were lucky enough to see a couple of elephants and lots of Bird life.

That is very beautiful amazing place to visit.kumana situated 15 km away from Panama town.That road also not a carpet one.You could see the animal on that area also.You can rent a jeep from Arugam Bay or entrance of the park.It was really nice experience. We saw many animals and also very beautiful birds. Environment also very beautiful.We visited in very hot season.Even difficult to find water.But park area's tanks were full with water. It's about 360 km away from Colombo. Trackers said it will be very beautiful after rain.
Visited this beautiful place on February 2016 and camped a night..had the best experience in camping..will be visiting soon again!

We did camping in Kumana last year. There are several camping sites inside the park. You need to reserve in advance through the Department of Wild Life. You have a great chance to see leopard and lot of elephants. Kumana is popular for bird watching. There are hundreds of varieties of birds. Safari Jeeps need to be booked form private suppliers. But not mandatory to book in advance. There are lot available in Panama area. It is difficult to reach park entrance by a car because road is not in good conditions. Vehicle with high ground clearance recommended.
All the good things that you get in Yalla, but without the hundreds of jeeps. We were very keen to try and see a bear but unfortunately we just missed it!! saw leopard, and lots of wonderful birds

Kumana Villu ( Lake ) is a wonderful place to visit and spend time in the months of June July and August. The Villu would have water and mangrove trees each on which birds like Painted Storks, Grey Herons, Pelicans, Darters, Purple Herons, Eurasian Spoon bills, Cormorants would be making nests or rearing the offsprings... The whole area reverberate with chirping noises from thousands of birds.. There is a watch tower where you can keep your tripod and telephoto lens to photograph the feast of a birder...

Kumana National Park is well worth a visit if you are in Arugam Bay. The park is about one hour drive from Arugam Bay. We saw elephants even before we entered the park and the drive to the park was really beautiful. We saw many big crocodiles, deer, water buffalo, birds, elephants, rabbit and in the end we also saw a leopard crossing the road in front of us! That made the safari. The nature in the park is very beautiful and quiet, we only saw three other jeeps so we pretty much felt we were alone in the park. Well worth the money it costs (and you can make good deals in Arguam Bay)!

The other day, after lunch we continued on our way to Kumana National Park, stopping at a pond and small creek where we saw the number of crocodiles in one place. Our guide took us to spots where we could closely, but safely observe these prehistoric reptiles. We also had a chance to encounter many of the regions birds, water buffaloes and monkeys that call the pond their home. And just on the edge of the park, at the Okanda Hindu Shrine. The temple has many colourful sculptures of Hindu Gods and we could learn about the stories behind these gods from a local priest. We enter the park at around 3-3:30 it was said that the best time for entering park, we found ourselves in one of the most bio diverse park in Sri Lanka. The park has several lagoons that are surrounded by tropical thorn forest. We were able to see monkeys, water buffaloes, elephant herds and jackals.

Visited to Kumana National Park on 18th April 2016 with my family, relations and family friends. When we visited to Ampara(3rd day of our trip)and following day suddenly we decided to go there. It took nearly two hours to go there. We bought water and snacks before go there. We had to buy those things before pass the Arugambay area. We had to travel nearly half an hour from main road to park entrance point. It's a gravel road very dusty because of no rain. At the entrance we had to pay nearly 100 per person as entrance ticket charge ( sorry I can't remember the exact amount ). If we like we can hire a person from National park staff to guide us. It's a good idea. We entered to the park using our own vehicles ( two vans ). Due to dry weather condition roads were not wet and muddy because of that we could go by our vehicles, but we had to careful from gravel roads with bad conditions. I recommend to go by hired Safari jeed. Rs.  6000 for a jeep, eight persons can go. If you are a bird lover, you have to go early morning to watch birds. We could see different kinds of birds, Deers, alligators, Elks, Wild pigs, Peacocks, Elephants, Foxes. If you are a photographer bring good lenses with well zooming capability. Because our busy schedule we had to turn back from the first bird watching point ( cement built place). We travel nearly 15 km's to that point from the start. It took one and half hours to get there. When we discuss with park staff, they told us May and June months are the best time to come and watch birds. Birds season ends in August. They informed us overnight camping area also available inside this park. We are coming back again to see all places of this park and watch many varieties of birds and animals, also stay overnight in this amazing Kumana National Park.

Entered this national park with the ambition of visiting Madamethota devalaya (also known as Kuda Kebiliththa) which is located at most southern point of this national park. This national park is full of wild life just like YALA national park. The two parks are separated from Kumbukkan oya. Mainly you can find tuskers, elephants, spotted deer, leopards and Sri Lankan bear. Also this place is famous for migrant birds. If you are visiting to Arugam bay, do not hesitate to pay a visit to this famous national park. Safari jeeps can be easily arranged from Arugam bay town. You can visit Okanda dewalaya and Kudumbigala Aranya Senasanaya (Buddhist temple) on the way to this national park.

We decided to go on safari at the Kumana Park during our Arugam Bay stay. We did a morning tour and were almost alone the whole time. We haven't seen many elephants (3 in total) but the nature is great and we have seen millions of water buffallos, deers and beautiful birds. We liked the tour!

Beautiful park with a lot of wildlife. The road to the park is already beautiful. You can do this strech with a scooter (though there are big elephants present!) or tuktuk and can see everything except maybe the leopard. But the park is worth the extra money. Scenery is very nice. Many birds, eliphants, crocodiles, fox, deer and many more. We saw within 10 minutes a big leopard.

We found a budget friendly jeep and drove to the park. Before we entered we already saw monkeys and crocs. At the entrance we paid additional 2000 rupees each (4 persons). Inside we saw jackals, birds, deer, buffalos, wild boar, more crocodiles and a huge elephant. We drove pretty close to it, i would say at about 50 meters. Of course we didn't see any leopards or bears, as they are really hard to spot. You can also see marshes, lagoons and a dry zone vegetation. That was something for the eye. The road is extremely bad, so prepare for a bumpy ride.

We few friends visited the park in January 2016 and spent a night at Thummulla Bungalow. Nice place with no hassle like other parks which you can see lots of birds. Thummulla Bungalow has been refurbished recently and staff there is very friendly. It is advisable to go by 4x4 vehicle, otherwise you will miss to reach some areas.

Visited the national park after the arugam bay trip!! The entire stretch of gravel road is filled with rare flowers and birds !! We were lucky to spot 4 big crocodiles waiting for their prey !!! Different kinds of crane with different colors!! Recommend to go on a jeep since the road is bumpy all the way !! We stopped at kudumbigala Rock where you could get a sky view of national park !!! Overall awesome place to have a road trip !!!!

We went to Kumana on a morning drive from Arugam bay. we were with only 4 people in the car so we had plenty of room. Already when we arrived at the entrance we were greeted by 10-30 monkeys. Inside the park we saw a few elephants, some deer and 4 leopards. Our guide heard the couple of leopards from the watch tower near the wetlands so we rushed to the car and found the leopards where he expected to find them. Very worthwhile trip.

We rented a Safari tour Jeep from the small town of Kataragama. Our excellent driver and the beauty of nature can only get 5-stars however it is a tiring tour to take on for an entire day and I would go with the half-day version next time. The park is huge and you need an experienced and caring tour guide to explain the little details (like bird nests sightings, and what footsteps belong to which animal) but also to find the ultimate sighting of the leopard/s! Our driver scoured the grounds until we finally saw the magnificent feline! If you are lucky enough, you might also run into the single unruly tusked elephant that is known to throw a feat with the jeeps!

we were almost alone at the park. Though we did not see any leopards, we had the opportunity to watch crocodiles, elephants, special birds, water buffalos, pickocs and more. this is a different safari, at least at this time of the year (late september) because the park is almost empty from visitors. Very special opportunity to enjoy nature.

We camped in the park which was great and although we did not see any Leopards we did see 3 sets of prints and narrowly missed seeing a bear (people in other car saw only minutes before).  The birds were amazing and a number of elephants, deer, boar, hare, buffalo etc. Could have spent much more time at the large waterhole than we had.  Well worth the visit if you are also going to other parks

We came with a jeep from Arugam Bay which was pretty close and easy to arrange. We ended up seeing almost "all" the animals: even a leopard. The guide form the national park was great at spotting animals and pointing them out to us. Great experience and very convenient.

Kumana has been know to be a Bird sanctuary. Best time to visit is the morning shift. We went there in the after noon. We did spot plenty of birds but most being ones that you can easily spot. We also came across many deer's, foxes, crocs, elephants, wild bores, peacocks, buffaloes....etc. Bit disappointed that we didn't  come across any leopards. It was during the dry season we were there so most animals were struggling to find water..

We went on three game drives in Yala, and saw lots of animals and even a Leopard for a few seconds. We saw practically nothing in Kumana. My advice is don't even think about wasting your money during July/early August when the pilgrims are all marching right through the national park on their pilgrimage. They walk from Okanda through the park to Kataragama. All of the animals go into hiding. When we visited the park it was a few days after this, and all of the animals were still in hiding. We didn't even see an elephant grazing around. The mandatory guide they send along basically slept the while time and didn't bother looking for animals, so I added a photo of him sleeping. The safari's to Kumana from Arugam's Bay are far more expensive than the ones in Yala. However, we were the only jeep we saw all day, so it was much quieter than Yala. I would give it a go any other time of year though. We paid $100 for two people for a jeep. But we were quoted as much as $200.

Oh my. We went here for Sloth bear and Leopard and were not disappointed. Its a bit of a drive to get here as we stayed at Arugum Bay so the drive is about 50 minutes but when we got here there was no one in the park and we hardly saw another vehicle in the whole of three days with six drives. One morning we spend 72 minutes with a leopard walking/sitting on rocks before it decided to get somewhere cooler to rest. No other vehicles! If you had been to Yala you would be lucky to get three minutes before another vehicles turns up. Did I mention the birds? Fantastic lagoons with wildlife everywhere. Owls, raptures etc.

The best wildlife park in Sri Lanka, it is about 8 hours drive from colombo. Quit a long drive but well worth it. The best way to experience the park is camping, try to get a good reputed camping expert like Xtream tours, and enjoy the wilderness at its best. You will feel the difference as soon as you enter in to the park, no vehicles so late back, most of all no mobile coverage so you are one with the nature. In my experience you will see more leopards in Kumana than Yala, but they are very shy so don't get disheartened if they ran away. It's just that they are not used to vehicles that much. In May, I saw 4 leopards at once, so it's well worth the trip. Make sure to ask for a good guide from the Park office if you are travelling with your family, it's always better to talk to him and ask few basic questions about the park just to get an idea to assess him. Nearest hotels would be in Arugam bay about 40km from the park, so if you are staying there early drive would be the best. Park also have a bungalow (Thummulla) which can be reserved through the DWC (Department of Wildlife Conservation), if you are to book the same you need to plan a month ahead, further details pls access the department's official website. Thummulla bungalow is situated at a very good location, in front of a lake where you see loads of animal activities all day long. Clean place with real SriLankan authentic food. Really friendly staff who will attend to your needs and safety. Overall the best National park to visit in Sri Lanka.

Kumana unlike Yala is less explored by the tourists and there are more wild life to watch. The roads are better and the guides are more friendly and knowledgeable. We saw herds of wild buffaloes, a vast population of wild boar, Porcupines, Mongooses, spotted deer and two leopards so close to the jeep. Peacocks are every where and so are the jungle fowls. In the water Painted storks, Wooly necked storks, Spot billed Pelicans, Purple moorehen, jaccana, Asian open bill , Lesser adjutant stork, litte egret, Great egret, Purple and Grey herons are in plenty along with teals. In one area there were hundreds of malabar Hornbills flocked astonishingly. The Kumana Villu was almost dried up and we watched pelicans, painted storks and other waterbirds in nests with nestlings. A wonderful sight to watch. there was a white bellied sea eagle trying to snatch nestlings... A very good national park .
Not a huge amount to see beyond water buffalo and peacocks, very very very busy with 4x4s bumper to bumper the whole way - yala west on the cheap

We took a Jeep Safari with Terrel Berenger  (Terrel Residences in Ampara) to the park with hopes of seeing elephants.  We were at the right place (we saw feesh signs), but the timing was not right on that day.  Regardless, we had an interesting ride in the jungle and saw birds, monkeys, and a beautiful lake.

We visited Kumana National Park in September 2014.  The drive to the Park is just as good as the drive in the actual National Park, once you have got your permit and can enter the Park.  We had a jeep safari, booked through our Hotel, which was great.  The only disadvantage we had was our "Guide" had poor English.  The Guide comes with you as you enter the Gate at the Kumana National Park.  We saw a lot of wildlife but unfortunately we didn't get to see a leopard.  In September, the park is very dry so try to go really early or late evening so you get to see plenty of wildlife. The park entry costed our family 6,000 rups (2 adults and 2 children).  We also had the expense of hiring a jeep.

I visited Kumana again. The distance from Colombo is 8 hours by road. If wildlife is the agenda, a night stop at the closest tourist destination of Arugam Bay is good enough. The distance to the park is about 40km from there. A jeep is a must for the park ride and that costs between 5,000 to 7,000 LKR. This is about US $ 40-50 and mostly Indian make jeeps. The park ride of about 2 hours gave me enough opportunity to sight leopard, tusker, wild boar and numerous bird. In 2 hours I saw more wildlife than I would aspire to see in two days in Yala. For additional reading pl refer the following link from my visit in 2009. http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2010/08/01/kebilitta-arugam-bay-and-kumana/

Kumana National Park was earlier known as Yala East Park. But in 5th September 2006 it was changed to Kumana. You will find more than 20 tanks and lagoons in this national park. Kumana bird Sanctuary was started way back in 1938. With in the same vicinity you get peep in to the Kutumbigala Forest Monastery as well.

Kumana being situated in the east coast is not easily accessible for the casual traveller. It would take 10 hrs to get there from Colombo once you throw in a few breaks. The park is a must if you are visiting Arugam Bay. The park itself offers a lot. I saw Spotted Deer, Wild Buffalo, Wild Boar, Jackals, Crocs, Sambor, Barking Deer, Mongoose, Monitors and of course the Majestic Elephant. I had a fleeting glance of a Leopard but didn't see the elusive bear. Kumana has always been known for its birds. And this year was no exception. 4 varieties of eagles, 2 varieties of owls, shama, painted stork, barber, green bee eaters, peacocks, jungle fowls, doves, parrots, pelicans, wild quail, kingfishers, woodpeckers, weevers, darts, & plenty of common birds were all seen. The best part of the trip was the camping by the river handled exceptionally well by Xtream Nature Tours of Colombo. I highly recommend them for anyone hoping to do a camping trip to Kumana since the father of the owner was the previous warden of the park and has an amazing knowledge if the entire park and plenty of adventures to talk over a BBQ and camp fire.

Formerly known as Yala East National Park, Kumana is next to Yala and is part of an ancient civilization. The park was closed from 1985 to 2003 because of LTTE terrorist activities. It was also affected by the Boxing Day tsunami in 2004. We entered the park at 6.15am and were the first visitors. We saw birds including the painted stork, peacocks, wild buffalo, wild boar, monitor lizards, crocodiles, deer, elephants etc etc. We were not lucky to see leopards nor bears. Since we visited in Jan, the park was green after the rains and not dusty. We spent half a day inside the park, even walking up to see rock inscriptions dating back to the 1st and 2nd century BC and caves.

I visited Arugambay and being an wildlife lover. ..I decided to visit Kumana national park.  What a fantastic experience....I was fortunate enough to be taken there by Najeem Safari tours.  Najeem was just the best guide for me.  We saw plenty of Elephants and deer everywhere....lots of jackels, crocodiles,wild pigs, wild buffaloes and funny monitor lizards.  Enjoyed it so much that I decided to return with Najeem safari tour for a nights camping experience. Well it was just amazing. ..we camped right next to a crystal clear river.  The food was excellent. ..all very well organised.   Recommended is a midnight swim in the river to the sounds of Elephants stomach rumbles. .call of the deer and odd leopard grunt.   Awesome.   To top it off, on the early morning drive was lucky enough to finally spot a leopard with 2 gorgeous cubs.  What a treat.   Will definitely return and go again with Najeem and his great sense of humour and knowledge of the bush.  Thanks Najeem safari tours.

With the reopening of the Kumana national park nearly two years ago, camping within Kumana had become a fad among the wildlife enthusiast that five main campsites maintained by the Department of Wildlife requires booking a good three months before. Birders who visit the Park are usually amazed at the sheer diversity of species that call Kumana home mainly due to the presence of 20 lagoons and tanks. These tanks are generally less than 2 metres deep and are often flooded by seawater and are spread throughout the park. Many campsites are located close to the water tanks and the Kumbukkan Oya, which forms the Southern boundary of the national park. The favourite among the five sites is the Gal Amuna Camp Site, Which stands by a natural rock Dam across the Kumbukkan Oya. The site is vast and surrounded by Kumbuk trees and provides a front seat view of the animals ranging from a vast number of birds to deer, elephant and leopards coming to the river for a drink. The naturally formed pool provides a rare crocodile free bathing spot to the campers. Heraligas Ara and Madametota too stand near the Kumbukkan Oya but are not the ideal bathing spots due to current and crocodiles. Yet the camping sites amply provide for the lack of water sports and animals and birds gathering by the river during the night and morning are sure to keep campers awake. The two Eda Kumbuka camp sites, thus named for the famous twisted Arjun tree nearby, too face the Kumbukkan Oya and are two scenic sites situated few hundred meters apart. They offer many photographic opportunities, with or without animals, yet the proximity to the river means keeping a safe distance from the banks as the water level tends to record a sudden rise. The two river mouth camping sites, named for their closeness to the delta of Kumbukkan Oya occupies prized location between the river and the Indian Ocean and is ideal for bird watchers and turtle enthusiasts. The campsites, maintained by the Wildlife Department has to be pre-booked and a guide had to be secured while an off track vehicle is an essential due to state of the roads. However private campsite operators too function inside the Kumana Park and provide semi luxury and luxury camping options.

We Visited kumana national park on recommendation by the owners at Hideaway resort. Paid about SGD 40 per person for the jeep(shared with a british couple) and abit more for the entrance fee at the park. There is a concentration of wildlife at the park entrance and then on its mostly birds. Left for the park at arnd 1pm from arugam bay and it seemed abit disappointing at first as it was mostly birds and buffalos. However in the short period of time (probably the last hour before sundown, there is a burst of wildlife around the waterholes. We were lucky, saw spotted deer crocodiles, jackals, elephants, a sloth bear walking alongside the jeep, and the elusive leopard which seemed to be stalking peacocks until the jeep approached to near and scared it away. a really fantastic experience for me and my girlfriend.

Kumana National Park is one of the final frontiers for me. It has got so much of history & wildlife that you would never want to come out of the park. Bambaragastalawa & Bowattegala are a couple of areas with lots of ancient caves with drip ledges, ancient inscriptions, statues and many more. The ancient stories of Nittewo (the ancient half-human, half-animal people who lived before the Veddas) are also connected with Kumana. The famous Kebiliththa can also be reached from Kumana National Park. Don't venture into this location without proper knowledge since even though you do not believe in the Old World Order, it still believes in you. I was a non-believer as well, but it all changed when I was punished for being too COCKY.. (PM me for more details) Kirigalla Bay is one of the hidden beaches of the country where it stretches for more than a couple of miles of pristine clear beaches. Turtles come to lay eggs in this beach as well. For me Kumana was never a wildlife hot spot. It was an add on. However Kumana has all the animals that the country has to offer, such as leopards, sloth bears, wild elephants, jackals, wild boar, spotted deer & many species of birds.

I pleasant, late afternoon adventure by safari jeep (operated by Dulip Kokuhannadige for Surf n Sun in Arugam Bay) meant that we saw more wildlife than most safari experiences. We took along our 6 year old granddaughter to view the event and we were delightfully rewarded with sighting elephants, crocodiles, iguanas, monkeys, a fox, a civet and Junglefowl (the national bird), Spoonbills and eagles abound. Sadly, the leopard alluded us this visit as did the bear. Next time....

I traveled here in June 2012 and it was perfect. i was fortunate to take my own off road vehicle & we cruse through the park with our ranger. Since this park was opened recently, not much animals are comfortable seeing humans :) we were chased by an elephant & it made our visit even more exciting. Similar animals population to Yala National Park but with less tourist. We were wishing we could spot a leopard,but unfortunately we didn't. plenty of elephants, birds, and reptiles to see & this park has some breathtaking meadows & landscapes. i advice you to go in the evening to witness scenery & animals roaming around. Even you can camp in the jungle next to a river. You're in for a surprise as soon as you enter the park, There's deer roaming around the administration office :) apparently she prefer to live in that vicinity.
The park had many animals and birds as it was just after the rains the tracks were really muddy and our safari vehicle since it had no four wheel drive got bogged down twice but a great experience
I wold like all of my trip with them,and also always arrange my food in side the kumana national park,also had good way back to monty hotel.
